etymologies: Old English; earliest use found in Chrodegang of Metz's Regula Canonicorum. From classical Latin hippocentaurus (in post-classical Latin also ippocentaurus) from ancient Greek ἱπποκένταυρος (from ἱππο- + κένταυρος; opposed to ἰχθυοκένταυρος fish-centaur)

definitions: A mythical creature with the body and legs of a horse and the head, arms, and torso of a human being (typically a man); a centaur.
